title: Business Live: Wall Street falls - BBC News
summary: gdp rises by a better than expected 0.4 % in third quarter .
sterling up by 0.24 % against the dollar following figures .
lloyds bank third quarter profits up by 9 % .

documents.title: good night
text: that 's it for tonight on business live .
we 'll be back bright and early at 06:00 on thursday morning .
do join us for all the latest breaking news and analysis from the business world .

documents.title: wall street ends down
text: us stocks ended lower , due to disappointing quarterly earnings reports from some companies and a rise in bond yields .

the fell 112.09 points , or 0.48 percent , to 23,329.67 , the s & p 500 lost 11.97 points , or 0.47 percent , to 2,557.16 and the nasdaq composite dropped 34.54 points , or 0.52 percent , to 6,563.89 .
dow jones ended the day at 23,329.46 , falling 112 points or 0.48 % .
the s & p 500 ended down 12 points or 0.47 % at 2,557.15 .
and the tech-heavy nasdaq closed at 6,563.89 , a drop of 34 points or 0.52 % .

documents.title: uber teams up with barclays
text: uber and barclays are teaming up in the us to launch a free rewards-enriched credit card .
the uber visa card will come with a $ 100 starting bonus , cashback on spending , 2 % on uber rides and an annual $ 50 credit on digital subscription services .
earlier today , visa 's quarterly profit expectations beat analysts ' expectations due to higher card swipes .
visa already has a partnership with uber that lets riders earn ride credits for buying goods at participating merchants .

documents.title: getting political
text: fashion label jigsaw has taken a political stance with its new pro-immigration fashion campaign .
is this becoming a new trend amongst businesses ?
why are businesses taking a stand on political debates ?
it seems pro spain fashion .

documents.title: legoland to open in new york
text: merlin entertainments has announced that it will open a $ 500m ( £ 377m ) legoland theme park in goshen , new york in 2020 .
construction will be starting soon and is expected to attract between 1.5-2.5 million people a year , according to cnn .
however some citizens are concerned that the theme park will lead to an increase in local traffic , a loss of active agricultural lands and damage to the environment .

documents.title: panel blunder
text: an all-male panel on women in business has been scrapped after the organisers received widespread ridicule on twitter .

sj magazine was intending to hold an event in november entitled `` women in business : a man 's point of view '' , inviting a university president , a politician , a tv sports correspondent and a health care executive to comment .
however , within hours of announcing the event , the us magazine decided to cancel it , after receiving numerous complaints on social media .
statement from sj magazine

documents.title: housing benefit wo n't be capped
text: the uk government has announced that it will not cap housing benefit for people living in social rented accommodation .
full details of the new housing benefit policy will be announced on tuesday 31 october , theresa may said during prime minister 's questions .
`` i can also say today that as part of our response to the review , we will not apply the local housing allowance cap to supported housing , '' she said .
`` indeed , we will not be implementing it in the wider social rented sector , and the full details will be made available when we publish our response to the consultation . ''

documents.title: more on that move
text: want to read more on the headhunt for jay hunt ?
the bbc 's media editor has it covered .
jay hunt becomes latest senior exec to leave traditional uk tv industry behind .

documents.title: apple on the hunt
text: a bit of media industry news .
apple has hired jay hunt - the former controller of bbc one and chief creative officer of channel four - to join its video team .
ms hunt was responsible for tv shows including sherlock and luther at the bbc before helping channel 4 sign up the great british bake off .
her title at apple will be creative director , europe , worldwide video .
apple has not specified what it involves , but she is expected to commission programmes on its behalf .
you can read more about that here .

documents.title: bad share day
text: wall street 's is having something of a bad day .
dow jones and s & p 500 indexes are both currently down around 0.7 % .

according to reuters it 's a combination of downbeat corporate earnings and contradicting signals on republican plans for a popular retirement scheme that 's to blame , coupled with doubts over whether trump can deliver on his tax reform plans .

company results for the third quarter have actually been pretty positive so far , but with indexes at record levels its hard to keep spirits consistently up that high , so some investors are looking at valuations .

documents.title: deutsche bank to pay $ 220m in us libor probe
text: deutsche bank has agreed to pay $ 220m to settle us regulatory charges that it defrauded government and nonprofit entities by manipulating libor and other benchmark interest rates .
the settlement between the german bank and attorneys general of 44 us states and washington dc was announced by new york attorney general eric schneiderman .

documents.title: breaking up
text: europe 's once-largest independent private bank sal oppenheim is to be broken up and integrated into deutsche bank , according to german national newspaper handelsblatt .
sal oppenheim was on the verge of collapse in 2010 when deutsche bought it for €1bn in cash .
the troubled cologne-based lender 's asset management and private wealth divisions will be integrated into deutsche , and the sal oppenheim brand will cease to exist .

documents.title: going electric
text: german car maker daimler has unveiled a prototype for an electric heavy duty truck at the tokyo motor show to compete with tesla .
according to daimler-owned mitsubishi fuso , the e-fuso vision one weighs 23,201kg and can drive 220 miles on a single charge .
tesla intends to release an electric semitrailer truck in november that is likely to have a driving range of 200-300 miles , as well as self-driving capabilities .

documents.title: may reassures mps over brexit vote timing
text: may reassures mps over brexit vote timing

documents.title: london closes down
text: the ftse 100 has closed down at 7,447.21 points - 79 points or 1.05 % down .
the biggest faller was drugmaker glaxosmithkline , despite seeing a rise in third-quarter sales and profits .
meanwhile , the ftse 250 fell 0.2 % to 20,073.30 .
the top loser of the ftse 250 index was russian-owned steel maker evraz , after the firm reported a decrease in short interest .

documents.title: would you let amazon into your house ?
text: amazon has launched a service whereby customers trust its staff to walk into people 's homes to deliver parcels .
to ensure security , customers will be able to watch the delivery take place using an app , an internet-enabled security camera and a smart lock .
amazon service will let couriers open front doors
what could possibly go wrong ?
always-on microphones , and now this !
the security services must be loving people bringing surveillance kit into homes for them .
no .
u trust this ? ?
amazon really pushing boundaries , maybe they can unpack parcels and put away too ?
i would n't trust amazon logistics with this .
we have to pay for it ? ! ?
fuck that !
if they want to make deliveries easier for themselves , make them free .
fuck that shit .
mi casa es no su casa
nope

documents.title: sterling continues to rise
text: the pound is now up 0.95 % against the dollar at $ 1.32600 , following higher than expected uk gdp growth for the third quarter , prompting hopes of an interest rate rise in november .
sterling is also ahead 0.58 % on the euro at €1.12310 .

documents.title: competition is key
text: oxford university 's professor dieter helm , the author of a new independent report reviewing the uk energy market , says that consumers are paying more than they need to , and not benefiting from falling costs .
`` in any healthy market , companies should be able to make profits , but they should not be able to make excess profits due to lack of competition , '' he told bbc business .
`` i suggest there should be a default tariff that is absolutely transparent and set out all the components of the cost and the margin that the companies charge on top .
`` it 's that simplification of the default tariff that will bring in entrants who are not part of the energy industry into the consumer market . ''

documents.title: all aboard the driverless bus
text: it may look like a fisher price toy but in fact , this is driverless bus .
german rail company deutsche bahn unleashed its first-ever auto bus on the spa town of bad birnbach , set in the rolling hills of bavaria .
here the 12-person bus , made by french startup easymile , will offer free rides to people as part of a test period .
after enjoying its inaugural journey , richard lutz , chief executive of deutsche bahn , said : `` we 've just driven autonomously into a new era of transport . ''

documents.title: 'scrap standard variable tariffs ' says beis energy review
text: as we reported earlier , an independent report by oxford university 's professor dieter helm has found that uk consumers and businesses are paying too much for their energy .

he is calling for a default tariff to replace the standard variable tariff , based on an index of wholesale costs , the fixed costs passed onto customers , fixed levies and taxes , and `` a published supply margin '' .

documents.title: peace diamond
text: the government of sierra leone is to auction off a huge uncut diamond in december , in order to raise funds for clean water , electricity , education and health projects in the country .
the 709-carat gem , known as the `` peace diamond '' , is the 14th largest in the world .
the government hopes to raise millions of dollars at the new york auction in december .
it previously rejected a bid of $ 7.8m ( £ 5.9m ) at an initial auction in sierra leone 's capital freetown in may .

documents.title: and the winners
text: on the dow jones , visa is currently topping the winners with shares up 1.2 % , trading at $ 109.70 , due to strong payment volumes , net income and operating revenues .

over on the s & p 500 index , it 's all about us health insurance firm anthem , which is up 5.7 % , with shares trading at $ 206.41 , on the news that it is to acquire medicare advantage company america 's 1st choice .
and finally on the tech-heavy nasdaq , medical device company nuvasive is up 9.4 % , trading at $ 59.71 on better than expected third quarter earnings .

documents.title: losers
text: further to our post on wall street , ge is leading the losers on the dow jones , with shares down 1.5 % , trading at $ 21.56 - their lowest in four years .
this week has been a bad one for ge - on monday its stock plunged 6.3 % , and then on tuesday slid down another 1.9 % .

on the s & p 500 , top loser mexican restaurant chain chipotle fell 14.21 % , with shares trading at $ 278.21 , due to revenues falling from the effects of hurricane irma and harvey , as well as a malware attack in april .
and on the tech-heavy nasdaq , chipset manufacturer amd 's stocks plunged 9.3 % to trade at $ 12.93 due to a disappointing fourth quarter profitability forecast .

documents.title: government 'should establish independent energy operator '
text: the review of the uk energy sector by professor dieter helm of the university of oxford recommends a number of actions designed to push the cost of uk energy down .

one of the recommendations is that the government should `` establish an independent national system operator and regional system operators ( rsos ) in the public sector , with relevant duties to supply , and take on some of the obligations in the relevant licences from the regulated transmission and distribution companies . ''

they would then auction `` functions and enhancements '' to networks , which would bid for `` network enhancements , generation and storage , and demand-side response ( dsr ) from energy service companies . ''

documents.title: wall street flat on open
text: wall street was flat on opening due to a handful of companies reporting lackluster earnings results .
the dow jones is flat at 23,446.42 , up just 5 points or 0.02 % .
the s & p 500 is down 2.9 points or 0.11 % to to 2,566.28 .
and the tech-heavy nasdaq is at 6,599.99 , up 1.6 points or 0.02 % .

documents.title: helm review : energy costs too high
text: the costs of uk energy are too high , according to an independent review of the energy sector commissioned by the government .
the `` cost of energy '' review by economist professor dieter helm says there should be harmonised carbon taxing and pricing in place of `` multiple interventions '' by the government .
`` prices should be falling , and they should go on falling into the medium and longer terms , '' the review says .
`` households and businesses have not benefited as much as they should because of legacy costs , policies and regulation , and the continued exercise of market power , '' he adds .

documents.title: indian bank stocks soar after $ 32bn recapitalisation plan
text: shares of indian banks rallied on the back of moves to inject $ 32.4bn ( £ 24.7bn ) to recaptialise the country 's state banks over the next two years .
state bank of india , the biggest lender , surged more than 20 % , while punjab national bank rocketed more than 33 % .
those gains help send the benchmark nse index up 1.3 % , touching a record high .
the plan , announced by india 's cabinet late tuesday , is designed to deal with mounting bad loans and help boost flagging growth .

documents.title: fearless girl company promises equal pay
text: the company behind the `` fearless girl '' statue on wall street has vowed to turn over a new leaf when it comes to equal pay for women .
state street global advisors paid a $ 5m settlement following claims of unequal pay from 305 female workers .
chief executive ron o'hanley tells cnbc that the financial services firm has `` not been perfect '' but is `` committed to equal pay for equal work '' .

documents.title: make yourself comfortable
text: woman is only passenger on holiday jet
happened to me once too !
and you surely felt as if you were the owner of that plane inevitable feeling .
yea the most awkward part was watching the crew do the whole safety procedure i was trying so hard to keep a straight face ' lol
if i were you , i would join the crew in the nose compartme , cause it 's not fair to be alone during the whole flight .
i 'm not completely sure whether that 's good or bad ! ? !
not news or unusual either .
a very common occurrence at the start / end of the season to have very low loads one way .
work it out
kick back and chill !
brilliant !

documents.title: crunch time for fruit growers
text: fruit growers warn they are `` counting down to catastrophe '' if the government does n't introduce a new seasonal workers scheme within the next year .

the uk needs more than 10,000 seasonal workers per annum to handle an orchard fruit crop worth £ 180m , according to a report by consultancy andersons midlands prepared for the trade body english apples & pears .
the report says growers face `` insurmountable difficulties '' in recruiting uk staff , and as a result most workers come from the european union .
english apples & pears chief executive steven munday said : `` the 2019 crop - and with it the future of the industry - is at stake .
`` until now the vast majority of our labour has come from europe , but there are currently no post-brexit guarantees that this will continue .
`` it is no use waiting until march 2019 when we leave the eu to see what happens .
we have to organise our workforce about a year in advance , so september 2018 is the deadline for a seasonal workers scheme to be in place .
he adds : `` without this , the consequences for growers , consumers and the environment will be devastating . ''

documents.title: watch : how to make a hologram
text: microsoft has opened a hi-tech studio dedicated to creating mixed reality content to be viewed via the hololens augmented reality headset .
the bbc 's north america technology reporter dave lee checked it out .
follow dave lee on twitter @ twitterid

documents.title: nice work if you can get itbbc technology correspondent tweets
text: great chart - what celebs can earn for social media endorsements

documents.title: dr pepper loses some fizz
text: results from another us soft drinks firm now .
dr. pepper snapple saw profits lose some fizz in the third quarter , although sales rose .
profits came in at $ 201m , down from $ 217m for the same period last year , a decline of 7 % .
the group said a loss on the recent hurricanes and earthquakes in the us and mexico was in part to blame .
sales revenue for the quarter rose 3.6 % to $ 1.74bn .

documents.title: boeing sales and profits grow
text: boeing 's third quarter sales rose by 2 % to $ 24.3bn , the defence giant announced on wednesday .
pre-tax profit for the three months to 30 september rose to $ 2.6bn from $ 2.2bn a year earlier .

documents.title: sterling rises above $ 1.32
text: the pound is now up 0.9 % against the dollar at $ 1.32530 following higher than expected uk gdp growth for the third quarter which has increased the likelihood of an interest rate rise in november .
sterling is also ahead 0.82 % on the euro at €1.12580 .

documents.title: northrop grumman lifts profit forecast again
text: us defence company northrop grumman says that sales for the third quarter to 30 september rose by 6 % to $ 6.5bn .
pre-tax profit reached $ 785m compared to $ 769m in the same quarter last year .
it said revenue rose across its three divisions : aerospace , mission systems and technology services and lifted its full-year profit forecast for the third time this year .
northrop grumman is expected to benefit from increased demand for f-35 fighter jets , for which it supplies the centre fuselage .

documents.title: gsk performance 'on course '
text: sales at pharmaceutical giant glaxosmithkline grew by 4 % ( when measured in actual exchange rates ) in the third quarter , helped by demand for new products .
as a result it said it was `` on course for our full-year earnings guidance '' .
sales hit $ 7.84bn - up from $ 10.38bn in the same period last year .
pharmacuticals sales grew by 3 % `` reflecting continued strong growth `` in the new respiratory and hiv products .
consumer healthcare sales rose by 5 % - driven by the pain and oral health brands , including panadol and sensodyne .

documents.title: coca-cola profits jump
text: coca-cola reports a 38 % jump in quarterly profit to $ 1.45bn , helped by cost-cutting and higher demand for sprite and tea and coffee in north america , its biggest market .
however , net revenues fell by 15 % to $ 9.1bn which the soft drinks maker attributed to a shift in its bottling operation to a less capital intensive franchise model .
nevertheless , it maintained its full-year forecasts .

documents.title: blackberry 's bet on driverless cars
text: blackberry has shifted its attention to autonomous car software after it licensed the rights to make smartphones under its brand to other firms .
the company 's chief executive john chen told the bbc that there was room for several players in the self-drive auto market .

documents.title: 'four rate rises by end of 2019 '
text: berenberg 's senior uk economist kallum pickering says he expects the bank of england to raise rates by 0.25 % four times between now and the end of 2019 - once next week and then twice next year and once ni 2019 .
and he says the rate setters are right to go for an increase next week .
`` even though real gdp growth has slowed a little this year compared to 2016 , because of brexit , firms are not supplying goods and services quickly enough to meet the growing demand .
`` as a result , underlying inflation is rising .

without modestly tighter monetary policy to keep inflation expectations firmly anchored at the 2 % target , underlying inflation would continue to rise and the boe would have to raise rates by more at a later date which would risk choking off the expansion .
it is far safer for the boe to go early and slowly than later and faster , '' he says .

documents.title: uk should use negotiators for brexit , says lord sugar
text: lord sugar reckons the uk is n't sending the right people to brussels to negotiate the uk 's exit from the european union .
he tells the bbc 's today programme : `` this is the most important thing that has happened to the uk since the first world war .

`` people do n't seem to understand how important a move this is and when you send someone to the negotiation table you do n't send a politician there , you should send someone who is used to being able to negotiate . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: miners drag ftse 100 lower
text: the ftse 100 is now down 9 points or 0.12 % at 7,517.88 .
miners dominate wednesday 's fallers .
antofagasta is down by nearly 4 % after a disappointing forecast for copper production .
fresnillo also declined by 2.4 % after giving a third quarter production update - even though it reported reported a 24 % increase in third-quarter silver production .
and anglo american shed 1.7 % , despite a 6 % rise in output for the third quarter .

documents.title: missing the boat
text: john eastgate , sales and marketing director of onesavings bank , says that new mortgage lending is being driven by first-time buyers and government initiatives such as the help to buy scheme .
`` with a rate rise in the offing however , borrowers may well have to face up to the reality that they 've missed the opportunity to secure the lowest mortgage rates in history , '' he says .

documents.title: consumer borrowing up , but firms cut back
text: gross mortgage lending in september was 5 % higher than the same month last year at £ 21.4bn , according to estimates by uk finance - which represents 300 of banking and finance firms in the uk .
credit card borrowing from high street banks rose by 5.5 % compared with last year , while across the whole market it was 7.8 % higher .

however , business borrowing has `` moderated over the course of 2017 , with the growth rate for borrowing by wholesale and retail businesses slowing the most , as these customer-facing sectors could be affected by any cutbacks in consumer spending '' , the group said .

documents.title: stagecoach siblings split
text: scotland 's best-known business siblings have gone their separate ways to invest their fortunes .
ann gloag and sir brian souter split the wealth they were managing together `` to follow very different investment strategies '' .
the announcement was made in the annual accounts of souter investments group , which handles sir brian 's assets .
read the full story here .

documents.title: struggling to recoverresolution foundation 's chief economist matt whittaker tweets
text: on an annualised basis , growth of 1 % means we 've now had 44 consecutive quarters of growth falling below the long-term average of 2.3 %
gdp per person is 2.5 % higher than at the start of the 2008 recession ( 9 1/4 years ago ) .
it was 18.8 % higher at same stage of 1990 recovery
looking further back , here 's how the recent downturn and recovery compares with cycles since 1929 .
the chart 's pretty , but the news is n't
worth saying of course that the uk is n't alone in facing difficult times post-crisis
despite the gloom , q-on-q growth of 0.3 % in q3 is roughly twice the pace recorded in both q1 & q2 and probably cements a rate hike next week
any chance you have a source or original publication for this ?
thanks .

the earlier data is from the bank of england 's 'millennium of macro data '

thing .

documents.title: big remains the same
text: john hawksworth , chief economist at accountancy firm pwc , says that the third quarter gdp figures `` do not change the big for the uk , which is of an economy that has slowed due to higher inflation linked to the weak pound and brexit-related uncertainty dragging on business investment '' .
but he adds : `` we should not overdo the gloom as there is nothing in this or other recent data to suggest that the slowdown is in danger of turning into a recession .
`` there is also nothing in these figures that would cause the mpc to hold off on the quarter point interest rate rise that markets expect from their meeting next week .

documents.title: any interest rate rise will be small
text: the slightly better growth figures will strengthen the arguments of the interest rate hawks on the bank of england 's monetary policy committee .
next week , the bank 's rate setting committee meets to decide whether to raise interest rates for the first time in more than a decade .
with inflation at 3 % , the governor mark carney ( has signaled that an increase is on the cards .
and with economic growth more robust than many economists expected , those who support that direction of travel on the mpc will be emboldened .
to be clear , any rate rise will be small .
and future rate rises will be gradual .
but the bank is sending a clear message - slowly , eventually , the period of historically low interest rates is coming to an end .
author: Kamal Ahmed
Economics editor

documents.title: pound rises on dollar and euro
text: the pound is now up 0.32 % against the dollar at $ 1.31760 following better than expected gdp figures and an increased likelihood of an interest rate rise .
sterling is also ahead by 0.21 % on the euro at €1.11900 .
hamish muress , currency analyst at ofx , says it is unlikely that the bank of england will now embark on a series of rate rises .

`` instead , it should signal a move out of 'emergency mode ' for the bank of england , providing the bank with the ability to lower rates once again , should the economy need a boost around the brexit deadline in 2019 . ''

documents.title: uk economy in 'second gear '
text: etx capital 's seniro market analyst neil wilson says the gdp figure was `` hardly a significant beat '' .
`` this is an economy stuck in second gear , '' he adds .
`` year-on-year growth stands at 1.5 % , which if it continues would be the weakest expansion since the crisis .
the productivity puzzle remains unsolved - gdp per head lagged the headline number and increased by just 0.3 % . ''

documents.title: ftse loses more ground
text: let 's check in now on how the ftse 100 is doing - and following the rise in the pound it has fallen further .
a short while ago it was down 0.40 % at 7,496.37 .
many ftse 100 firms are big exporters and they tend to lose out when the pound strengthens .

documents.title: gdp is 'last part of the jigsaw ' for bank
text: commerzbank economist peter dixon says wednesday 's gdp figures represent `` the last piece in the data jigsaw '' ahead of next week 's bank of england meeting on the interest rate .

he says : `` there is now nothing standing in the way of the monetary policy committee acting on the message which it has been giving to the market since september that a near-term rate hike is warranted . ''

he adds : `` from a signalling perspective , it might be difficult for the mpc to avoid a rate hike next week and still maintain the market credibility required to sustain its forward guidance policy . ''

documents.title: gdp : the chancellor reacts
text: more reaction to those gdp figures , now - this time from the chancellor of the exchequer , philip hammond .
we have a successful and resilient economy which is supporting a record number of people in employment .

my focus now , and going into the budget , is on boosting productivity so that we can deliver higher-wage jobs and a better standard of living for people across the country , '' he said in a statement .

documents.title: bank of england will remain cautious
text: ben brettell , senior economist at hargreaves lansdown , says gdp make an interest rate rise more likely .
`` yet if rates do rise as expected , the move will be largely symbolic - though it will be the first rise in over 10 years .
`` a 25 basis point increase merely reverses last year 's cut - which was arguably unnecessary - and returns rates to where they 've been for the entire post-crisis period .
`` i expect the bank to proceed with caution from here . ''

documents.title: end of the pay squeeze ?
text: ruth gregory , uk economist at capital ecomomics , says : `` the third quarter figures leave the economy on track to grow by about 1.6 % this year .
`` looking ahead , with inflation likely to fall in 2018 , the worst of the real pay squeeze should soon be behind us .
and sterling 's decline , along with robust global growth , should boost net trade over the coming quarters . ''
she suggests that as a result , gdp will grow by around 2 % in 2018 .

documents.title: rate rise might be 'premature '
text: geraint johnes , professor of economics at lancaster university management school , thinks an interest rate rise next week could be `` premature '' .

he says : while many commentators were suggesting that a figure above 0.3 % might signal an interest rate hike in november , the outturn figure represents stable but slow growth - certainly well below trend .
unless the bank of england 's agents ' reports , which are due out on 8 november , point to an unexpected degree of wage pressure , an early increase in the interest rate would be premature . ''

documents.title: gdp raises possibility of rate risebbc economics editor kamal ahmed tweets
text: 0.4 % growth better than expected .
will ease spending pressure on chancellor and embolden mpc on possibility of a interest rate rise @ twitterid
i think you are out of depth as bbc economics correspondent .
your views are so london-centric
@ twitterid @ twitterid @ twitterid so does that mean vat will go back to 17.5 % since interest rates are going to rise
put this in context ?
b4 brexit we were top performing in eu , now we are worst ?
are we where we were 10 years ago - ie during the crash ?
@ twitterid context is all .
0.4 % is dire .
maybe better than expected but still dire .
why are you not saying this ?
about time interest rates went up and up and up
int analysis on manufacturing production output `` that it cld be down 2 bad mgmt , lack of investment '' gov can aid , but biz must take resp .
can we believe anything economists predict with reference to brexit when they get every single forecast wrong ? ? ?
they are frankly useless
real body blow to remainers .
0.4 % q3 2017 gdp is laughable .
it 'll be music to ears of terrorist bank of england .
@ twitterid are bad liars .
carney and the mpc will still bottle it .

documents.title: services and manufacturing boost gdp
text: the ons 's head of national accounts darren morgan says : `` growth in the third quarter of 2017 continued at a similar rate as seen in the first half of the year .
`` services , led by increases in it , motor trades and retail , continued to drive gdp growth .
manufacturing also boosted the economy with an improved performance after a weak second quarter .
but he adds : `` construction output fell for the second consecutive quarter , although it remains above its pre-downturn peak . ''

documents.title: services drive growth
text: as henrietta grimston told bbc breakfast , just how well the services sector is doing is important because it comprises such a big part of the overall economy .
0.2 % growth in the service sector in august , led by business services & finance ( +0.3 % ) # gdp

documents.title: pound rises on higher gdp figures
text: sterling rose by 0.24 % against the dollar at $ 1.3165 following the better than expected gdp figures .
gdp growth of 0.4 % for the third quarter is ahead of consensus forecast for 0.3 % .

documents.title: uk gdp outstrips expectationsons tweets
text: 0.4 % growth in # gdp in q3 with growth led by services , particularly it , motor trades and retail
something to behold watching # brexiters celebrate uk underperforming the eurozone .
whole point of # brexit was to do better not just survive ?
suspect many under-40s have come to terms with the fact that you ca n't stop globalisation in this age .
the penny has n't dropped for others .
congratulations on writing a great uk gov tweet .
( ranked 35th for oct 25 . )

documents.title: breakinguk gdp grows at 0.4 % in third quarter
text: the uk economy grew at 0.4 % between july and september , according to the office for national statistics ( ons ) .

documents.title: gdp : what to look for
text: let 's get a quick reminder of what we 're expecting from those economic growth figures in a few minutes and what to look out for .
colletta smith spoke to henrietta grimston , an investment adviser .
`` the expectations of growth are of about 0.3 % for this quarter and that 's pretty much in line with what we 've seen for the last two quarters in the uk .

`` now the important underlying numbers are things such as retailing and consumer spending and that 's because here in the uk services , which include the retail numbers , are 80 % of gdp , so the consumers here are very important .

`` the other driving factor behind that services sector is business investment particularly from the likes of financial services and as we 've seen business seem to be very reticent at the moment to invest until they have some certainty of the brexit outcome . ''
author: BBC Breakfast

documents.title: all wrapped up ?
text: ahead of the gdp figures , business presenter colletta smith was at a cardboard factory in leamington spa - a good barometer of how the economy 's doing because so much of what we buy is packed in boxes - and if it 's doing well , it means retailers are doing well .
the box company produces three million boxes a month .
colletta spoke to managing director neil price and asked him how business had been so far this year .
`` this year we have found it 's been good , '' he said .
`` it 's been challenging for us and our customers , actually .
we 've been subjected with raw material increases due to sterling exchange rates rates and a shortage globally of paper so our margin has been eroded this year .
however , he added : `` we 're finding our customers are generally busy .
`` i think everybody is cautious .
i think we 're all waiting for brexit and the outcome of that and i think it 's an interesting time .
`` i think uk plc will be fine and i think the future looks rosy . ''
author: BBC Breakfast

documents.title: invest , improve skills and take risks
text: lord o'neill says that uk employers have preferred to take on cheaper labour .

to improve productivity , he says we need to improve the labour force 's skills and to recognise that there is a major regional difference - with areas such as the north and the midlands as `` very , very weak '' .
he adds that the uk needs to incentivise business owners to stop hoarding cash and managing the balance sheet and take more investment risks and put money into equipment .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: uk workers lag us and europe
text: why is it that it takes a british worker five days to produce what a french , german or american employee can make in four days ?
economist lord o'neill questions whether the way the uk actually measures productivity might be a problem .

he says with the growth of technology and companies such as airbnb : `` it 's quite possible that we are underestimating the level of gdp and therefore productivity might be higher than is being officially recorded . ''
even so , lord o'neill reckons the uk would still have a significant productivity problem , which has got worse over the past decade .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: japan stocks snap record winning streak
text: tokyo 's benchmark index has ended its longest winning streak in its history .
the market posted an unprecedented 16 straight days of gains , helped by prime minister shinzo abe 's victory in sunday 's election , which raised hopes for continued stimulus .
the nikkei 225 lost 0.5 % , or 97.55 points , to finish at 21,707.62 , weighed down by losses for exporters .
elsewhere in asia , south korea 's kospi added 0.1 % to close at 2,492.50 , while australia 's s & p/asx 200 index also put on 0.1 % to end at 5,905.6 .
hong kong 's hang seng was up 0.4 % in afternoon trading .

documents.title: m & s confirms departure
text: m & s has confirmed that its clothing boss , jo jenkins , has resigned .
yes , we can confirm she 'll be leaving us .
she 's been with us a few years and she 'll be moving on to become the ceo of white stuff , an outdoor sportswear company .
`` this is the natural next professional career step for her and we 're delighted . ''
ms jenkins will stay with m & s in the short term as she 's serving out her six-month notice period
while it 's too early to say who may replace her , her departure wo n't leave us with a gaping hole '' , says m & s , as it has a managing director for clothing and home in place , jill mcdonald .

documents.title: 'm & s clothing boss quits '
text: marks & spencer‎ 's ( m & s ) clothing boss has resigned , according to sky news .

the broadcaster says it 's learned that jo jenkins , who has only been in the post of director of clothing‎ and beauty , for a few months , is to leave to join white stuff , the privately owned clothing chain .
her defection will be seen as a bitter blow to stephen rowe , who took over as m & s 's chief executive last year , says sky .

documents.title: virgin money set for all female leadership
text: virgin money is in advanced talks with irene dorner , the former boss of hsbc 's us business , to chair the banking group .
her appointment would mean that virgin money would have the only all-female leadership team in the ftse 350 .
its chief executive is jayne anne gadhia .
ms gadhia told a cross party woman in finance committee on tuesday that financial services had a `` very male culture '' and sexism was `` pervasive '' .
however , she said that the industry had improved at dealing with sexism .

documents.title: the chancellor 's conundrum
text: the ifs 's paul johnson says : `` the reason why george osborne and now philip hammond have continually failed to meet their budget targets to get in to balance despite big spending cuts is because productivity has failed to grow . ''

he says : `` the office for budget responsibility are hinting very strongly that they 're going to take a fairly gloomy view of what 's going to happen to productivity over the next four or five years - gloomier than back in march .

`` now if they do that , they 're going to say the economy 's going to grow less than they thought , that means the tax revenues are going to come in less quickly and that means philip hammond is going to have less money to spend and then he 's going to have some really tough decisions . ''
mr johnson says mr hammond will either have to accept the demands of his backbenchers and others to lift spending and therefore borrowing .
or will he say that because the economy is n't doing well , he ca n't afford to do this .
`` he 's not going to find either of those at all comfortable , '' says mr johnson .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: hasta la vista , ppi
text: lloyds has been dogged by claims over the mis-selling of payment protection insurance .
it 's already paid out more than £ 18 billion to affected customers .
the city regulator , the fca , is running an advertising campaign , starring arnold schawarzeneger 's voice , urging people to claim quickly .
as a result , lloyds says it 's been receiving up to 16,000 new claims each week , far more than it had been expecting .
but it has n't had to set aside any more money to pay for them .
perhaps lloyds is finally saying `` hasta la vista '' to its costly ppi misbehaviour .
author: Rob Young
Business presenter

documents.title: london treads water at open
text: in london the ftse 100 index has opened slighly lower at 7,519.71 - a fall of 7 points or 0.09 % .
the ftse 250 is flat at 20,112.57 .

documents.title: ppi deadline 'concentrates minds '
text: lloyds was the bank most affected by the ppi mis-selling claims and has already paid out more than £ 18bn to affected customers .
however in the third quarter it did not put any extra money aside for ppi claims
`` i think this is actually partly because the government has now imposed a deadline which concentrates people 's minds amazingly , '' frances coppol told rob young on today .
`` so now they will be getting more claims but the end is in sight .
so i think what they 're saying is they 've got sufficient provisioning to see it all through - and they 're on the road now to seeing that disappear . ''
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: lloyds boosted by lack of ppi provision
text: one of the main reasons that lloyds profits have jumped in the third quarter is because it did not have to set aside any extra money to cover payment protection insurance ( ppi ) mis-selling claims , whereas in the the same period last year it had to set aside £ 1bn .
however ppi claims did go up .

the bank said that `` ppi claim levels increased as expected in the third quarter following the financial conduct authority advertising campaign ( reaching around 16,000 per week and have now reduced to 11,000 per week , above our assumed run-rate of around 9,000 per week '' .

documents.title: lloyds 'able to operate more freely '
text: earlier this year - in may - the government sold the last of its shares in lloyds bank .
on today rob young asks independent banking analyst frances coppola if that shift back into private hands has made a difference to how the bank is run .

`` i think being partly in government ownership does create the feeling that you 've got politicians looking over your shoulder , whereas now it 's back in the private sector it 's able to operate more freely and more in relation to what it 's owners and its customers need , '' she says .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: dairy body calls for brexit 'continuity '
text: dairy body calls for brexit 'continuity '
author: Conor Macauley
BBC NI Agriculture & Environment Correspondent

documents.title: why is lloyds doing well ?
text: more on those lloyds results now , and on today business presenter rob young asks just why the bank 's results are so good .
it 's got out of its doldrums , it 's cleaned up its balance sheet , it 's recovered from its acquisition of hbos , which was really what the problem was , and it 's moving on .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: britain 's productivity problem explained
text: commenting on the uk 's poor productivity - which measures how much we produce an hour - paul johnson , director of the institute of fiscal studies , says : `` the problem essentially is that number has n't risen over the last 10 years at all . ''

he tells the bbc 's today programme : `` what you expect over the longer run , or certainly what we 've got used to , is that it increases by perhaps 2 % a year as you get better equipment at work , education improves , the investment improves so you would expect productivity to rise .

`` if productivity is n't rising then wages are n't rising because if you 're not producing any more then you 're not going to get paid any more and the two things have failed to rise in concert over the last decade or so since the financial crisis . ''
he says that we are seven years into austerity but the country still has a large deficit which limits how much the chancellor philip hammond can spend .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4
